+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 78.0
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The room stank of alcohol and ozone, a familiar perfume to anyone who had ever tuned a machine with a pocketknife and a prayer. The ruined city hummed outside the cracked glass like a hive at fever pitch, glass and concrete rippling with heat mirages that bent the skyline into impossible shapes. In here, under a dented metal hood that raggedly hung from a shelf, a canopy of glow-in-the-dark mushrooms crawled along tile grout, their bioluminescent caps casting a pale, shifting green over battered benches and rusted incubators. I listened for the distant thump of a failing power line, for the sigh of a ventilation duct coughing up ash. What I heard instead was the soft, rhythmic clack of a microcentrifuge that hadn’t been properly balanced sine days after the exodus. It spun with the stubborn bravery of a thing that had outlived its manufacturer’s warranty—if such a thing existed anymore, which it didn’t. So we learned to tune by ear. I’m Mara, a biohacker with a toolbox full of salvaged promises. My town—if you could call it a town—squatted near the old harbor, a ring of tin-roof shanties stitched together with scavenged copper and fear. Our settlement called itself the Seed, because we recalled the old world’s stubborn faith in growth, in the idea that a plant could be coaxed into giving life again if you coaxed the right dream out of it. The problem came when the old corporations designed DNA to die with the generation that bought it. One generation. One harvest. One miracle. Then nothing. No memory, no revival, no second chance. Just a seed that refused to remember yesterday. The mushrooms marked a kind of diary on the floor: spores that glowed when the lab lights flickered out, a reminder that the old experiments hadn’t disappeared so much as evolved into a kind of fungal graffiti. Their mycelium threaded through the cracks like pale green veins, feeding on the leavings of old splicing tests—PCR stripes of dried gel, leftover antisense remnants stuck to the edges of petri dishes. It made the place feel haunted and hopeful all at once. The contract lay on a battered clipboard like a trap. The buyer’s name was a rumor I’d heard in a market stall and forgotten five minutes later, replaced by a scent of rain and copper coins. What mattered was the supply: seeds that would thrive in our climate, crops that would resist the rot, proteins that would hold up against the gnawing cold that crept into night-time air. What mattered more was the means to obtain them—illicit, shining with the sheen of risk. The market for second-rate genetics hadn’t vanished; it had just learned to whisper. You paid with favors and a few measurable risks, and you hoped your luck was better than your faith. The pipeline sat on a bench, a Frankenstein of scavenged parts. A centrifuge built from a coffee grinder and a car’s ABS sensor hummed with a stubborn life that no manual could coax into obedience. A thermocycler—our own ugly, glorious misfit—was nothing more than a plastic-laced dream chassis, its temperature cycle controlled by a dial that clicked with the sound of a coin falling into a wishing well. A real PCR would have been a clean, sterile affair, but here, sterile was a suggestion and clean was a myth. We used a patchwork of gloves that didn’t quite fit, and a hood with a torn outer sleeve that did more to shield us from dust than from anything biological. The lights flickered in a rhythm that reminded me of lit cigarettes being smacked out against a wall, and I counted the pulses as an index of safety. “Ready?” Jax asked. He was lean as a reed, eyes bright with the calculus of risk. He wore a patchwork coat that had once sheltered a different life—manufacturers’ logos now faded into a memory of better days, days when people believed in the audacity of a living design. He was the broker of the deal and the courier of parts, a man who could turn a rumor into a toolkit with nothing but a whispered trade and a wrench. “Ready enough,” I said, though the truth was more complicated. Our latest crop wouldn’t be a standard hybrid; it would be something volatile, something like a memory that forgot to die. The company line—taught in classrooms that no longer existed—claimed DNA lasting a generation. Our reality, however, was a chorus of fragments: fragments of genes, of promises, of copper wires and dark fuel. We were stitching together a recipe with threads that frayed at both ends, hoping the middle would hold long enough to harvest what we needed. The plan took shape in our heads as I wheeled the cart closer to the epoxy-lacquered bench. We’d splice for viability, not perfection. The seeds we needed to propagate food crops required a different trick: not perfect memory, but a stubborn, adaptive forgetfulness that could be coaxed into persistence. In theory, the transgene would pass through a generation and vanish; in practice, we hoped it would remain long enough to germinate in the next season’s soil. We began with a simple, brutal sequence: extract, amplify, insert. The old protocols were a broken chorus line, repeated until they knew the steps by heart. I pulled a vial free from its improvised rack—a glass tear-drop of amber, the color of dried honey, labeled with a hand-drawn glyph that had survived more years than I cared to admit. The label bore the ghost of a corporate logo, now faded, replaced by a rough scrawl of corrections and a crude warning: not tested beyond the fourth generation, not guaranteed under any condition. It was exactly the sort of label that would get us killed in the old world, and exactly the sort of label that kept us alive here. The first step was to cultivate a sterile environment the best we could. We used salvaged laminar flow under a roof that leaked when it rained, biasing the air to blow outward and away from the work. The mushrooms grew in the grout between tiles, their glow a soft warning to stay close to the benches and not drift toward the door where the wind carried in the rumor of warring factions and disease. We wore makeshift respirators: swapped-foam masks with filtered cartridges scavenged from an old hospital supply. The cartridges carried a tang of formaldehyde and something else—an antiseptic memory that hadn’t quite faded yet. Jax pipetted a small amount of the sample into a tube that had once belonged to a different drug’s clinical trial—an artifact of a pharmaceutical world that never believed in long-term safety for anyone except the bottom line. We added a trace of buffer, a pinch of salt, and then the magic: a gene drive that would bias inheritance toward our favored crops. The bees of the old world left the fruit to the wind; we would leave the fruit to the soil, to be nursed by the sun and the rain, not by a committee in a boardroom. The process was an iteration of hope and risk. The degradation of genetic material—the built-in obsolescence that had supposedly been engineered into the DNA—made every step a countdown. Each cycle could degrade the newly introduced sequences, leaving us with nothing but a memory of what could have been. We watched the fluorescence in a borrowed detector, a device that glowed when a successful binding occurred, and waited for a signal that the dream of perpetual food had not died in the hands of greed. In the glow of the mushrooms, the room grew suddenly intimate. The bioluminescent caps cast phosphorescent freckles across Jax’s forearms, like star-trails that refused to fade. The physical toll of these experiments was a constant whisper in the back of my head: headaches that thudded when a failed reaction released a rush of toxins, a brittle taste in the mouth, knees that ached after long hours bent over a bench. The medicine we attempted was not just synthetic; it was untested, improvised, dangerous. But it carried something else too: a fragile relief, like a second heartbeat, when the body learned how to lean into the new genetics and survive the day. There had to be an upside, otherwise the night would swallow us whole. The old world had built obsolescence into every organism as though it were an act of mercy to the money men who watched from glass towers. But if the material died with the generation, maybe, just maybe, parts of it could outlive the ledger if we learned to read the signs. Some crops would bloom in unexpected places, stronger and more resilient than before. Some proteins would confer temporary resistance to disease, offered as a medicine for those who could not afford real care. It was a precarious faith, a belief that the degradation of DNA could be turned, by sheer stubbornness and cleverness, into something useful for a people who had learned to hunger and endure. The door’s hinge squealed as if offended by the intrusion of air. A shadow slid into the lab—too careful to be carefree, too hungry to be innocent. The buyer’s courier, a woman named Lita with a scar along her jaw that had nothing to do with knife work and everything to do with survival, looked at the scene with a practiced eye. She didn’t ask questions beyond what mattered: did the batch satisfy the contract, did the risk align with the reward, could we escape before a patrol or a raid interrupted our work and took everything we owned. “Show me the growth,” she said, not unkindly, but with the cadence of someone who knew where the bodies of old failures lay and how loud their silence could be in a room full of memory. I pointed to a petri dish that bore the faintest rings of growth, a greenish halo around a seedling that looked suspiciously like something that might have once grown in a greenhouse that expected more sun than a blackout would allow. The dish was our first evangel. If it worked, the colony would have a food source that could adapt to the climate and resist a little salt, a little rot, a little frost that crept in through the windows at night. Lita nodded, her eyes glinting with that pragmatic fire that had kept her alive through multiple postings and double-crosses. She bought the idea with the exacting patience of a trader who smelled a wind change before the market did. The price was not merely cash, but a pledge: that we would share the seeds if they survived, that we would trade for tools when possible, and that we would not publicize our methods in a way that could draw attention to the fragile ecosystem we had barely learned to cherish. In a world where corporations had scripted obsolescence into the genetic code, a black market deal like ours was a small rebellion, a spark in the dark, a promise that life could outpace the system—if only we could do two things at once: survive and remember to care for what we were growing. When she left, the mushrooms glowed brighter for a moment, as if savoring the absence of another human presence near the spliced dreams. The room settled. We returned to work, both of us with the same stubborn belief: that even in a world designed to fail, we could coax a stubborn harvest from the failing genetic memory. We could listen to the quiet chorus of the incubation chamber and the lab benches, and maybe, just maybe, we could hear a future pushing its way through the cracks in the tiles. The ship of our effort sailed on a thin, frail keel—the same kind of hope that had kept people alive during the long blackout of history. The glow in the mushroom tiles moved like a living calendar, marking the days and nights that passed as we labored, hopeful, uncertain, and hungry. The jury-rigged lab equipment pretended to function as the machines of a more hopeful era, while we learned to make do with what remained: a few useful genes, a handful of seeds, and the stubborn belief that life could endure, even when designed to forget how to remember. As the cycle ended and the chamber’s air finally cleared of the sharp sting of reagents, we stood back and looked at the quiet growth in the dish. The crop might not have been perfect, and the memory of the genetic insertion might fade with the next generation, but there was a sense of continuity, a rumor of abundance. The mushrooms kept glowing, a soft, patient warning that the world would not surrender to the night as quickly as the old regime had hoped. Outside, night curled around the ruined city like a black-blue cloak, and the first stars—if you still believed in stars after everything—began to show themselves in the gaps between the clouds. The contract lay in a pocketed drawer, the glow of the mushrooms reflecting a dozen small decisions that led to a single, stubborn line of survival: that in a world where DNA was designed to die so quickly, the human impulse to grow could still outlive the design, if only we were willing to work with what we had and trust the patient, dangerous work of turning memory into momentum.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter effectively creates a post-apocalyptic world where corporate greed has engineered built-in obsolescence into DNA. The narrative follows Mara, a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to create viable food crops for her settlement called "the Seed." The chapter centers around a black market contract with a buyer's courier named Lita. The worldbuilding is particularly strong, with vivid descriptions of jury-rigged lab equipment like "a centrifuge built from a coffee grinder and a car's ABS sensor" and a thermocycler described as an "ugly, glorious misfit." The author creates a tangible atmosphere of desperation mixed with ingenuity, showing how humans adapt to survive corporate-engineered collapse. The physical toll of using untested genetic modifications is addressed, though somewhat briefly, mentioning "headaches that thudded when a failed reaction released a rush of toxins, a brittle taste in the mouth, knees that ached after long hours bent over a bench." The unexpected upsides are also touched upon, describing "a fragile relief, like a second heartbeat, when the body learned how to lean into the new genetics and survive the day." The prose is often lyrical and evocative, creating a strong sense of place and mood. However, it occasionally veers into purple territory with metaphors that feel overwrought: "The mushrooms marked a kind of diary on the floor: spores that glowed when the lab lights flickered out, a reminder that the old experiments hadn't disappeared so much as evolved into a kind of fungal graffiti." Some passages become too dense with figurative language, slowing the narrative momentum. The black market contract plot is present but somewhat underdeveloped. While Lita's appearance provides tension, the stakes and specific details of the contract remain vague. The narrative meanders at times, focusing more on atmospheric description than advancing the plot. Character development is minimal. While Mara has a distinct voice and perspective, we learn little about her background or motivations beyond survival. Jax and Lita are thinly sketched, serving primarily as plot devices rather than fully realized characters. The dialogue is sparse but functional, though it lacks the distinctiveness that would make these characters truly memorable. The piece relies heavily on internal monologue and description rather than character interaction. Despite these weaknesses, the piece succeeds in creating a compelling post-apocalyptic world with a unique premise. The technical details about genetic engineering and jury-rigged equipment feel authentic and well-researched. The theme of human resilience against corporate exploitation resonates throughout, giving the piece thematic coherence.
